comments.text:
It's a film. The point is for the viewer to suspend disbelief and 
nitpicking at small details is not the point of viewing. If it doesn't 
create issues with the plot, then what's the big deal. Don Fanucci is 
killed by Vito in this scene. That's it.
comments.author: jw870206

comments.text:
The webley ammunition was a black powder round with a common lead round 
nose projectile. A fairly low velocity round that while fair sized was not 
the kind of bullet that had lots of penetration or made huge holes. It 
would be another few years before smokeless propellant or jacketed pistol 
ammunition was in common use. Getting shot through the cheek thru all that 
bone could have prevented the round from coming out. I think its a 
reasonable take on what it might have looked like.
 As for overkill, he wanted to ensure he was not getting up.
comments.author: Deenohh Vo

comments.text: +Russ Snyder A bit overkill if you ask me
comments.author: Ben Hislop

comments.text:
+Ben Hislop
 The gun used is .455 Webley revolver. Although the round is pretty big, 
they were black powder rounds and very low velocity (under 700 feet per 
second if I recall. Add that to a relatively unimpressive bullet design ( 
pretty sure they were just round nose unjacketed lead rounds) and it doesnt 
add up to an impressive wound. Third factor would be shots that damage the 
heart and reduce or stop blood pumping many times are not terribly bloody.
comments.author: Deenohh Vo

comments.text: +Maraak .Nor Fair point
comments.author: Ben Hislop

comments.text:
+Ben Hislop Small caliber rounds (or low-velocity) might not even create an 
exit wound, and a handgunbullet can also just go straight through as well 
if powerful enough.
The gun used is a .455 Webley is slow, but quite large as well (comparable 
to a .45), but people often overestimate the visual damage bullets will do 
to a human. Often it is just a small entry and small exitwound (tho the 
exit is larger than the entry), and the damage happens in between.

Also, similar to ''The first one is free'' of blood spatter analysis 
regarding stabwounds, i.e minimal immediate bloodspatter on the first of 
several attacks before getting progressively more gory with repeated 
attacks; A gunshotwound to the head can be ''undramatic'' to begin with, 
but repeated hits can cause more structural damage to the cranium. Similar 
to how the first bullet penetrating a window can just leave a single hole, 
and following hits will make it all come crashing down.
comments.author: Maraak .Nor

comments.text:
From the Godfather saga, the scenes of young Vito are by far my favorites. 
Little Italy, 1920's, those were the days where you could make a name for 
yourself out in the streets without ending up in jail the next day because 
of fingerprints, DNA evidence, cameras on every corner, etc. The "golden 
age" of the mafia has been over or a while now... it can only go downhill 
from here. ﻿

comments.text:
Not only the technology but the legal changes (RICO statutes especially and 
enhanced conspiracy laws and penalties) the reduction of the evidence 
thresholds needed for conviction and the increased sentences all added up 
pretty much to the end of the mafia as well as other organized crime groups 
that prefer to do business from locations that are a little more "business" 
friendly.

I love the old fashioned drama style death. A shot to the heart and he 
stands there, in disbelief, and still has the strength to rip open his 
jacket. In real life, he would have been stone cold dead the second the

So cool. Not too many movies take this kind of liberty with a gunshot 
death. Magic!﻿

comments.text:
+ennui2000 the traditional Mafia were not like Don Fanucci, who used a 
suppposed connection to a local gangster called Maranzalla to extort 
people. The main mafia frowned on the Black Hand members and avoided them 
and even protected Italians from them at times.

The Corleone family had their share of extortionists, but it was always for 
some business the family was interested in, or in Johnny Fontane's case, as 
a favor to him from the Godfather.
comments.author: SantomPh

comments.text:
The character of Don Fanucci represented the "old style" Mafia, where they 
got their way (extortion) by fear and intimidation, not so much with 
"muscle" always around him.  The "muscle" came in later if people didn't 
pay up.  Sonny, Michael, Tom Hagen, Virgil Sollozzo were the new, 
mercantile Mafia.  Don Vito Corleone was a transitional figure.
comments.author: ennui2000

comments.text:
In New York in 1920, Don Fanucci threatens Vito for a share from his 
robbery operations. Instead Vito has companions Clemenza and Tessio agree 
to his plan of paying Fanucci less, because he can make an offer he won’t 
refuse. Earning Fanucci’s respect, Vito stalks him during a Italia festa 
from the rooftops and shoots him dead at his apartment.
